abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Loan Project
            supports Korea's program of structural reforms. It
            builds on the work initiated under the Economic
            Reconstruction Loan, approved on December 23, 1997. The
            project will help Korea deal with the immediate foreign
            exchange crisis as well as support a major program of
            structural reforms in the financial and real sectors to lay
            the basis for Korea's eventual return to strong and
            sustained growth. The structural reform program spans four
            important areas: a) financial sector restructuring and
            development; b) corporate sector reform, including reform of
            corporate governance and competition policies; c) labor
            market reform and the strengthening of social safety nets;
            and d) institutional reform in economic policy management.
            There are some risks to the program. A key risk derives from
            Korea's still fragile macroeconomic situation, and its
            continued vulnerability to shifts in investor confidence. To
            mitigate this risk, the Bank will work closely with the IMF
            (International Monetary Fund), ADB (Asian Development Bank),
            and other partners. Another risk arises from the weakness of
            the domestic banking system. This project will expedite the
            process of financial sector restructuring and corporate debt
            workouts. There is also a risk that the economic downturn
            may be more severe than currently expected, which will be
            mitigated by the strong safety net measures. The loan will
            be disbursed in a single tranche upon effectiveness.
